           <dt>&#x226b; v&#x1e5b;ddhi 2</dt>
           <dd><em>v&#x1e5b;ddhi</em> f. (for 1. See p. 1010) growth, increase, augmentation, rise, advancement, extension, welfare, prosperity, success, fortune, happiness RV. &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; elevation (of ground) VarB&#x1e5b;S </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; prolongation (of life) Pa&#x00f1;cat </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; swelling (of the body) Su&#x015b;r </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; enlargement of the scrotum (either from swelled testicle or hydrocele) ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; swelling or rising (of the sea or of the waters), waxing (of the moon) MBh </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; gain, profit R. Subh </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; profit from lending money &amp;c., usury, interest Mn. Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;. MBh. (the various kinds of interest recognized by Hind&#x016b; lawyers are, 1. <em>k&#x0101;yik&#x0101; v&#x1e5b;ddhi</em>, 'body-interest', i.e. either the advantage arising from the body of an animal pledged as security for a loan, or interest paid repeatedly without reducing the body or principal </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 2. <em>k&#x0101;lik&#x0101; v&#x25cb;</em>, 'timeinterest', i.e. payable weekly, monthly, annually, &amp;c., but most usually computed by the month </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 3. <em>cakrav&#x25cb;</em>, 'wheel-interest', i.e. interest upon interest, compound interest </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 4. <em>k&#x0101;rit&#x0101; v&#x25cb;</em>, 'stipulated interest', at a rate higher than the usual legal rate </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 5. <em>&#x015b;ikh&#x0101;-v&#x25cb;</em>, 'interest growing like a lock of hair', i.e. at a usurious rate payable daily <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1011-2"></a>[Page 1011, Column 2]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 6. <em>bhoga-l&#x0101;bha</em>, 'advantage <em>accruing to a creditor</em> from the use' of objects handed over to him as security, e.g. of lands, gardens, animals, &amp;c.: 'lawful interest' is called <em>dharma-v&#x25cb;</em>, 'usurious interest' <em>a-ny&#x0101;ya-v&#x25cb;</em>, 'interest at the highest legal rate' <em>parama-v&#x25cb;</em>) IW. 264 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the second modification or increase of vowels (to which they are subject under certain conditions, e.g. <em>&#x0101;</em> is the V&#x1e5b;iddhi of the vowel <em>a</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ai</em> of <em>i</em>, <em>&#x012b;</em>, and <em>e</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>au</em> of <em>u</em>, <em>&#x016b;</em>, and <em>o</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#2">2.</a> <em>v&#x1e5b;ddha</em> and <em>k&#x1e5b;ta-v&#x1e5b;ddhi</em>) VPr&#x0101;t. P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. R&#x0101;jat. Sarvad </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; one of the 8 principal drugs (described as mild, cooling &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; and a remedy for phlegm. leprosy, and worms) Su&#x015b;r. Bhpr </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to rain down, shower down, pour forth, effuse, shed (&#x0100;. = 'to bestow or distribute abundantly' </dd>

           <dt>ve 1</dt>
           <dd><em>ve</em> (cf. &#x221a;<em>&#x016b;y</em>), cl. 1. P. &#x0100;. (Dh&#x0101;tup. xxiii, 37) <em>v&#x00e1;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (pf. p. <em>vavau</em> or <em>uv&#x0101;ya</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 2. sg. <em>uvayitha</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 3. pl. <em>vavu&#x1e25;</em> ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x016b;vu&#x1e25;</em> RV </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x016b;yu&#x1e25;</em> Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; &#x0100;. <em>vave</em>, <em>&#x016b;ve</em>, <em>&#x016b;ye</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>av&#x0101;s&#x012b;t</em>, <em>av&#x0101;sta</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Prec. <em>&#x016b;y&#x0101;t</em>, <em>v&#x0101;s&#x012b;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>v&#x0101;t&#x0101;</em> ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>v&#x0101;syati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>vayi&#x1e63;y&#x00e1;ti</em> RV </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>&#x00f3;tum</em>, <em>&#x00f3;tave</em>, <em>&#x00f3;tava&#x00ed;</em> ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>v&#x0101;&#x0341;tave</em> AV.), to weave, interweave, braid, plait (fig. to string or join together artificially, make, compose, e.g. speeches, hymns) RV. &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>

           <dd><em>vetrin</em> mfn. (ifc.) having a cane, having anything for a cane MaitrUp </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a staff-bearer, door-keeper R&#x0101;jat</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; vetr&#x012b;ya </dt>
           <dd><em>vetr&#x012b;ya</em> mfn. (fr. <em>vetra</em>), g. <em>utkar&#x00e2;di</em></dd>

           <dt>veda 1</dt>
           <dd><em>veda</em> m. (fr. &#x221a;1. <em>vid</em>, q.v.) knowledge, true or sacred knowledge or lore, knowledge of ritual RV. AitBr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of certain celebrated works which constitute the basis of the first period of the Hind&#x016b; religion (these works were primarily three, viz. 1. the &#x1e5a;ig-veda, 2. the Yajur-veda [of which there are, however, two divisions, See <em>taittir&#x012b;ya-sa&#x1e43;hit&#x0101;</em>, <em>v&#x0101;jasaneyi-sa&#x1e43;hit&#x0101;</em>], 3. the S&#x0101;ma-veda <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1015-2"></a>[Page 1015, Column 2]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; these three works are sometimes called collectively <em>tray&#x012b;</em>, 'the triple Vidy&#x0101;' or 'threefold knowledge', but the &#x1e5a;ig-veda is really the only original work of the three, and much the most ancient [the oldest of its hymns being assigned by some who rely on certain astronomical calculations to a period between 4000 and 2500 B. C., before the settlement of the &#x0100;ryans in India </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; and by others who adopt a different reckoning to a period between 1400 and 1000 B3. C., when the &#x0100;ryans had settled down in the Panj&#x0101;b] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; subsequently a fourth Veda was added, called the Atharva-veda, which was probably not completely accepted till after Manu, as his law-book often speaks of the three Vedas-calling them <em>trayam brahma san&#x0101;tanam</em>, 'the triple eternal Veda', but only once [xi, 33] mentions the revelation made to Atharvan and A&#x1e45;giras, without, however, calling it by the later name of Atharva-veda </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; each of the four Vedas has two distinct parts, viz. 1. Mantra, i.e. words of prayer and adoration often addressed either to fire or to some form of the sun or to some form of the air, sky, wind &amp;c., and praying for health, wealth, long life, cattle, offspring, victory, and even forgiveness of sins, and 2. Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;a, consisting of Vidhi and Artha-v&#x0101;da, i. e. directions for the detail of the ceremonies at which the Mantras were to be used and explanations of the legends &amp;c. connected with the Mantras [see <em>br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;a</em>, <em>vidhi</em>], both these portions being termed <em>&#x015b;ruti</em>, revelation orally communicated by the Deity, and heard but not composed or written down by men [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#I">I.</a> W. 24 &amp;c.], although it is certain that both Mantras and Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;as were compositions spread over a considerable period, much of the latter being comparatively modern </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; as the Vedas are properly three, so the Mantras are properly of three forms, 1. &#x1e5a;ic, which are verses of praise in metre, and intended for loud recitation </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 2. Yajus, which are in prose, and intended for recitation in a lower tone at sacrifices </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 3. S&#x0101;man, which are in metre, and intended for chanting at the Soma or Moon-plant ceremonies, the Mantras of the fourth or Atharva-veda having no special name </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but it must be borne in mind that the Yajur and S&#x0101;ma-veda hymns, especially the latter, besides their own Mantras, borrow largely from the &#x1e5a;ig-veda </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the Yajur-veda and S&#x0101;ma-veda being in fact not so much collections of prayers and hymns as special prayer- and hymn-books intended as manuals for the Adhvaryu and Udg&#x0101;t&#x1e5b;i priests respectively [see <em>yajur-veda</em>, <em>s&#x0101;ma-veda</em>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the Atharva-veda, on the other hand, is, like the &#x1e5a;ig-veda, a real collection of original hymns mixed up with incantations, borrowing little from the &#x1e5a;ig and having no direct relation to sacrifices, but supposed by mere recitation to produce long life, to cure diseases, to effect the ruin of enemies &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; each of the four Vedas seems to have passed through numerous &#x015a;&#x0101;kh&#x0101;s or schools, giving rise to various recensions of the text, though the &#x1e5a;ig-veda is only preserved in the &#x015a;&#x0101;kala recension, while a second recension, that of the Bh&#x0101;shkalas, is only known by name </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a tradition makes Vy&#x0101;sa the compiler and arranger of the Vedas in their present form: they each have an Index or Anukrama&#x1e47;&#x012b; <em>q.v.</em>, the principal work of this kind being the general Index or Sarv&#x00e2;nukrama&#x1e47;&#x012b; <em>q.v.</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; out of the Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;a portion of the Veda grew two other departments of Vedic literature, sometimes included under the general name Veda, viz. the strings of aphoristic rules, called S&#x016b;tras <em>q.v.</em>, and the mystical treatises on the nature of God and the relation of soul and matter, called Upanishad <em>q.v.</em>, which were appended to the &#x0100;ra&#x1e47;yakas <em>q.v.</em>, and became the real Veda of thinking Hind&#x016b;s, leading to the Dar&#x015b;anas or systems of philosophy </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the later literature the name of 'fifth Veda' is accorded to the Itih&#x0101;sas or legendary epic poems and to the Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;as, and certain secondary Vedas or Upa-vedas <em>q.v.</em> are enumerated </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the Ved&#x00e2;&#x1e45;gas or works serving as limbs <em>for preserving the integrity</em> of the Veda are explained under <em>ved&#x00e2;&#x1e45;ga</em> below: the only other works included under the head of Veda being the Pari&#x015b;ish&#x1e6d;as, which supply rules for the ritual omitted in the S&#x016b;tras </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the B&#x1e5b;ihad-&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;yaka Upanishad the Vedas are represented as the breathings of Brahm&#x0101;, while in some of the Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;as the four Vedas are said to have issued out of the four mouths of the four-faced Brahm&#x0101; and in the Vish&#x1e47;u-Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a the Veda and Vish&#x1e47;u are identified) RTL. 7 &amp;c. IW. 5 ; 24 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the number 'four' VarB&#x1e5b;S. [1015, 3] Srutabh </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; feeling, perception &#x015a;Br </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>v&#x1e5b;tta</em> (v. l. <em>vitta</em>) L. (cf. 2. <em>veda</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; vedas 1</dt>
           <dd><em>v&#x00e9;das</em> n. (for 2. See p. 1017, col. 3) knowledge, science RV. (cf. <em>keta-</em>, <em>j&#x0101;ta-</em>, <em>vi&#x015b;va-v&#x25cb;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; ved&#x0101;&#x1e45;ga </dt>
           <dd><em>ved&#x00e2;&#x1e45;ga</em> n. 'a limb (for preserving the body) of the Veda', N. of certain works or classes of works regarded as auxiliary to and even in some sense as part of the Veda, (six are usually enumerated <em>and mostly written in the &#x1e63;&#x016b;tra or aphoristic style</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 1. <em>&#x015b;ik&#x1e63;&#x0101;</em>, 'the science of proper articulation and pronunciation', comprising the knowledge of letters, accents, quantity, the use of the organs of pronunciation, and phonetics generally, but especially the laws of euphony peculiar to the Veda [many short treatises and a chapter of the Taittir&#x012b;ya-&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;yaka are regarded as the representatives of this subject </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but other works on Vedic phonetics may be included under it, <em>pr&#x0101;ti&#x015b;&#x0101;khya</em>]: 2. <em>chandas</em>, 'metre' [represented by a treatise ascribed to Pi&#x1e45;gala-n&#x0101;ga, which, however, treats of Pr&#x0101;k&#x1e5b;it as well as Sa&#x1e43;sk&#x1e5b;it metres, and includes only a few of the leading Vedic metres]: 3. <em>vy&#x0101;kara&#x1e47;a</em>, 'linguistic analysis or grammar <em>represented by P&#x0101;&#x1e47;ini's celebrated &#x1e63;&#x016b;tras</em>: 4. <em>nirukta</em>, 'explanation of difficult Vedic words' [cf. <em>y&#x0101;ska</em>]: 5. <em>jyoti&#x1e63;a</em>, 'astronomy', or rather the Vedic calendar [represented by a small tract, the object of which is to fix the most auspicious days for sacrifices]: 6. <em>kalpa</em>, 'ceremonial', represented by a large number of S&#x016b;tra works [cf. <em>s&#x016b;tra</em>]: the first and second of these Ved&#x00e2;&#x1e45;gas are said to be intended to secure the correct reading or recitation of the Veda, the third and fourth the understanding of it, and the fifth and sixth its proper employment at sacrifices: the Ved&#x00e2;&#x1e45;gas are alluded to by Manu, who calls them, in iii, 184, Pravacanas, 'expositions', a term which is said to be also applied to the Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;as) IW. 145 &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;&#x1e45;gat&#x012b;rtha </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;t&#x012b;rtha</em> m. N. of an author Cat</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;&#x1e45;gatva </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;tva</em> n. the nature or condition of a Ved&#x00e2;&#x1e45;ga, &#x015a;&#x0101;rvad</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;&#x1e45;gar&#x0101;ya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;r&#x0101;ya</em> m. N. of various authors (esp. of the son of Tigul&#x0101;-bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;a and father of Nandik&#x00ea;&#x015b;vara, who wrote for &#x1e62;ah Jeh&#x0101;n the P&#x0101;ras&#x012b;-prak&#x0101;&#x015b;a and the &#x015a;r&#x0101;ddha-d&#x012b;pik&#x0101;, A&#x1e0c;. 1643). <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1017-1"></a>[Page 1017, Column 1]</font>
</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;&#x1e45;ga&#x015b;&#x0101;stra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;&#x015b;&#x0101;stra</em> n. the doctrine of the Ved&#x00e2;&#x1e45;gas Jyot</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;&#x1e45;gin </dt>
           <dd><em>ved&#x00e2;&#x1e45;gin</em> m. one who studies or teaches the Ved&#x00e2;&#x1e45;gas MW</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; ved&#x0101;nta </dt>
           <dd><em>ved&#x00e2;&#x0341;nta</em> m. end of the Veda (= 'complete knowledge of the Veda', cf. <em>ved&#x00e2;nta-ga</em>) T&#x0100;r. MBh </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the second and most important part of the M&#x012b;m&#x0101;&#x1e43;s&#x0101; or third of the three great divisions of Hind&#x016b; philosophy (called Ved&#x00e2;nta either as teaching the ultimate scope of the Veda or simply as explained in the Upanishads which come at the end of the Veda </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; this system, although belonging to the M&#x012b;m&#x0101;&#x1e43;s&#x0101; <em>q.v.</em> and sometimes called Uttara-m&#x012b;m&#x0101;&#x1e43;s&#x0101;, 'examination of the later portion or <em>j&#x00f1;&#x0101;na-k&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a</em> <em>q.v.</em> of the Veda', is really the one sole orthodox exponent of the pantheistic creed of the Hind&#x016b;s of the present day - a creed which underlies all the polytheism and multiform mythology of the people </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; its chief doctrine <em>as expounded by "&#x1e63;a&#x1e43;kara</em> is that of Advaita i.e. that nothing really exists but the One Self or Soul of the Universe called Brahman <em>neut.</em> or Param&#x00e2;tman, and that the J&#x012b;v&#x00e2;tman or individual human soul and indeed all the phenomena of nature are really identical with the Param&#x00e2;tman, and that their existence is only the result of Aj&#x00f1;&#x0101;na <em>otherwise called &#x0101;vidy&#x0101;</em> or an assumed ignorance on the part of that one universal Soul which is described as both Creator and Creation </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Actor and Act </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Existence, Knowledge and Joy, and as devoid of the three qualities [see <em>gu&#x1e47;a</em>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the liberation of the human soul, its deliverance from transmigrations, and re-union with the Param&#x00e2;tman, with which it is really identified, is only to be effected by a removal of that ignorance through a proper understanding of the Ved&#x00e2;nta </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; this system is also called Brahma-m&#x012b;m&#x0101;&#x1e43;s&#x0101; and &#x015a;&#x0101;r&#x012b;rakam&#x012b;m&#x0101;&#x1e43;s&#x0101;, 'inquiring into Spirit or embodied Spirit' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the founder of the school is said to have been Vy&#x0101;sa, also called B&#x0101;dar&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a, and its most eminent teacher was &#x015a;a&#x1e43;kar&#x00e2;c&#x0101;rya) Up. MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;s</em>), m. pl. the Upanishads or works on the Ved&#x00e2;nta philosophy Kull. on Mn. vi, 83</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;ntakataka </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kataka</em> m</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;ntakath&#x0101;ratna </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kath&#x0101;-ratna</em> n. N. of wks</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;ntakart&#x1e5b; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kart&#x1e5b;</em> m. the author of the Ved&#x00e2;nta Pa&#x00f1;car</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;ntakalpataru </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kalpataru</em> m. (<em>&#x25cb;ru-&#x1e6d;&#x012b;k&#x0101;</em> f. <em>-parimala</em> m. <em>-parimala-kha&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ana</em> n. <em>-ma&#x00f1;jar&#x012b;</em> f.),</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;ntakalpadruma </dt>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;ntakalpalat&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kalpalat&#x0101;</em> or f</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ved&#x0101;ntakalpalatik&#x0101; </dt>

           <dt>&#x22d9; vedij&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;j&#x0101;</em> f. 'altarborn', epithet of Draupad&#x012b;, wife of the P&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;u princes (the fee which Dro&#x1e47;a required for instructing the P&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;u princes was that they should conquer Drupada, king of Pa&#x00f1;c&#x0101;la, who had insulted him </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they therefore took him prisoner, and he, burning with resentment, undertook a sacrifice to procure a son who might avenge his defeat </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; two children were then born to him from the midst of the altar, out of the sacrificial fire, viz. a son Dh&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e6d;a-dyumna, and a daughter Draupad&#x012b; or K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;&#x0101;, afterwards wife of the P&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;avas) L. - 2</dd>

           <dt>vedha 2</dt>
           <dd><em>vedha</em> m. (&#x221a;<em>vyadh</em>) penetration, piercing, breaking through, breach, opening, perforation VarB&#x1e5b;S. R&#x0101;jat. Sarvad </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; hitting (a mark) MBh </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; puncturing, wounding, a wound Su&#x015b;r </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. disease of horses L </dd>

           <dt>vai 1</dt>
           <dd><em>vai</em> (orig. identical with &#x221a;2. <em>v&#x0101;</em>), cl. 1. P. (Dh&#x0101;tup. xxii, 24) <em>v&#x0101;&#x0341;yati</em>, to become languid or weary or exhausted RV. (<em>&#x015b;o&#x1e63;a&#x1e47;e</em> Dh&#x0101;tup.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be deprived of (gen.) RV. viii. 47, 6 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; P. and (ep. also &#x0100;.), to blow &#x0100;past. MBh</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; v&#x0101;ta 3</dt>
           <dd><em>v&#x0101;ta</em> mfn. (for 1. and 2. See pp. 934, 939) dried up ( 1. <em>a-v&#x0101;t&#x00e1;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; v&#x0101;na </dt>
           <dd><em>v&#x0101;na</em> mfn. dried &amp;c. ( See 2. <em>v&#x0101;na</em>, p. 940, col. 2)</dd>

           <dt>vai 2</dt>
           <dd><em>va&#x00ed;</em> ind. a particle of emphasis and affirmation, generally placed <em>after</em> a word and laying stress on it (it is usually translatable by 'indeed', 'truly', 'certainly', 'verily', 'just' &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is very rare in the RV </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; more frequent in the AV., and very common in the Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;as and in works that imitate their style </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the S&#x016b;tras it is less frequent and almost restricted to the combination <em>yady u vai</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in Manu MBh. and the K&#x0101;vyas it mostly appears at the end of a line, and as a mere expletive. In RV. it is frequently followed by <em>u</em> in the combination <em>v&#x0101;&#x0341; u</em> [both particles are separated, v, 18, 3] <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1020-1"></a>[Page 1020, Column 1]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is also preceded by <em>u</em> and various other particles, e.g. by <em>&#x00ed;d</em>, <em>&#x00e1;ha</em>, <em>ut&#x00e1;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;as it often follows <em>ha</em>, <em>ha sma</em>, <em>eva</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in later language <em>api</em> and <em>tu</em>. Accord. to some it is also a vocative particle)</dd>

           <dt>vai&#x1e43;&#x015b;atika </dt>
           <dd><em>vai&#x1e43;&#x015b;atika</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. (fr. <em>vi&#x1e43;&#x015b;atika</em>) purchased with twenty P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 5-1, 27</dd>

           <dt>vaika&#x1e43;seya </dt>

           <dt>vai&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>vai&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;ra</em> n. the worId U&#x1e47;. iv, 159 Sch. ('the sky', 'the wind', or 'Vish&#x1e47;u' U&#x1e47;v&#x1e5b;.)</dd>

           <dt>vai&#x1e63;&#x1e47;ava </dt>
           <dd><em>vai&#x1e63;&#x1e47;av&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. relating or belonging or devoted or consecrated to Vish&#x1e47;u (q.v.), worshipping V&#x1e6d;Vish&#x1e47;u TS. &amp;c. &amp;c. ; m. patr. fr. <em>vi&#x1e63;&#x1e47;u</em> g. <em>bid&#x00e2;di</em> ; 'a worshipper of Vish&#x1e47;u', N. of one of the three great divisions of modern Hind&#x016b;ism (the other two being the &#x015a;aivas and &#x015a;&#x0101;ktas ; the Vaish&#x1e47;avas identify Vish&#x1e47;u - rather than Brahm&#x0101; and &#x015a;iva - with the supreme Being, and are exclusively devoted to his worship ; they have become separated into four principal and some minor sects, as follow: 1. the R&#x0101;m&#x00e2;nujas, founded by R&#x0101;m&#x00e2;nuja, who is said to have lived for 120 years <em>from 1017 till 1137 &#x0101;.&#x1e0d;.</em> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1027-3"></a>[Page 1027, Column 3]</font>
 ; his chief doctrines are described at p. 878, col. 1, and in RTL. p. 119 &amp;c. ; one peculiarity of his sect is the scrupulous preparation and privacy of three meals ; 2. the M&#x0101;dhvas, founded by a Kanarese Br&#x0101;hman named Madhva, whose chief doctrines are described at p. 782, col. 3, and in RTL. p. 130 &amp;c. ; 3. the Vallabhas, founded by Vallabh&#x00e2;c&#x0101;rya, whose chief doctrines are described at p. 928, col. 3, and in RTL. p. 134 &amp;c. ; 4. a sect in Bengal founded by Caitanya <em>q.v.</em> who was regarded by his followers as an incarnation of K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a ; his chief doctrine was the duty of <em>bhakti</em>, or love for that god which was to be so strong that no caste-feelings could exist with it [see RTL. p. 140 &amp;c.] Of the minor Vaish&#x1e47;ava sects those founded by Nimb&#x00e2;rka or Nimb&#x00e2;ditya <em>&#x1e5b;&#x1e6d;&#x1e3b;. 146</em> and by R&#x0101;m&#x00e2;nanda <em>&#x1e5b;&#x1e6d;&#x1e3b;. 147</em> and by Sv&#x0101;mi-N&#x0101;r&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a <em>&#x1e5b;&#x1e6d;&#x1e3b;. 148</em> are perhaps the most important, to which also may be added the reformed theistic sect founded by Kab&#x012b;r <em>&#x1e5b;&#x1e6d;&#x1e3b;. i 58</em> and the Sikh theistic sect founded by N&#x0101;nak <em>&#x1e5b;&#x1e6d;&#x1e3b;. 161</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of Soma (lord of the Apsarases) A&#x015b;v&#x015a;r </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;-</em>) of a poet Cat </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the 13th cubit (<em>aratni</em>) from the bottom or the 5th from the top of the sacrificial post L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of mineral L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (scil. <em>yaj&#x00f1;a</em>) a partic. sacrificial ceremony ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. patr. fr. <em>vi&#x1e63;&#x1e47;u</em> MBh </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a female worshipper of Vish&#x1e47;u Pa&#x00f1;car </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the personified &#x015a;akti of Vish&#x1e47;u (regarded as one of the M&#x0101;t&#x1e5b;is, and identified with Durg&#x0101; and Manas&#x0101;) MBh. R&#x0101;jat. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Asparagus Racemosus L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Ocymum Sanctum L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Clitoria Ternatea L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in music) a partic. M&#x016b;rchan&#x0101; Sa&#x1e43;g&#x012b;t </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. a partic. Mah&#x0101;-rasa (q.v.) Cat </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. prodigy or omen (belonging to or occurring in the <em>para&#x1e43; divam</em> or upper sky), M-W </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the ashes of a burnt-offering ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the Nakshatra&#x015a;ravana (presided over by Vish&#x1e47;u) VarB&#x1e5b;S </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of two S&#x0101;mans &#x0100;rshBr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of various wks., esp. of the Vish&#x1e47;u-Purl&#x1e47;a</dd>

Ved&#x00e2;ntas.: Caus. <em>-h&#x0101;rayati</em>, to allow any one to do what he likes Kull. on Mn. viii, 362 to deal with (acc.) SaddhP.: Pass. of Caus. <em>h&#x0101;ryate</em>, to be named or designated BhP</dd>

           <dd><em>vy-&#x0101;sa</em> m. severing, separation, division Sarvad </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; width, breadth, the diameter of a circle, &#x015a;ulbas. VarB&#x1e5b;S </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'distributing, disjoining', N. of the Pada-p&#x0101;&#x1e6d;ha or, disjoined text' Apr&#x0101;t </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'arranger, compiler', N. of a celebrated mythical sage and author (often called Veda-vy&#x0101;sa and regarded as the original compiler and arranger of the Vedas, Ved&#x00e2;nta-s&#x016b;tras &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he was the son of the sage Par&#x0101;&#x015b;ara and Satyavati, and half-brother of Vicitra-viirya and Bh&#x012b;shma </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he was also called V&#x0101;dar&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a or Baldar&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a, and K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a from his dark complexion, and Dvaip&#x0101;yana because he was brought forth by Satyavat&#x012b; on a Dviipa or island in the Jumn&#x0101; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; when grown up he retired to the wilderness to lead the life of a hermit, but at his mother's request returned to become the husband of Vicitra-viirya's two childless widows, by whom he was the father of the blind Dh&#x1e5b;ita-r&#x0101;sh&#x1e6d;ra and of P&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;u ; he was also the father of Vidura <em>q.v.</em> by a slave girl, and of &#x015a;uka, the supposed narrator of the Bh&#x0101;gavata-Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a, he was also the supposed compiler of the Mah&#x0101;-bh&#x0101;rata, the Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;as, and other portions of Hind&#x016b; sacred literature ; but the name Vy&#x0101;sa seems to have been given to any great typical compiler or author) MBh. Hariv. Pur., <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#IW">IW.</a> 371, n. 2 ; 373 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a Br&#x0101;hman who recites or expounds the Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;as &amp;c. in public (= <em>p&#x0101;&#x1e6d;haka-br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;a</em>) MW </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; thoroughly liberated or emancipated (as the soul) Kap </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ceased, disappeared, gone Kum </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; excepted, excluded W </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; praised, hymned (?) ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-kaut&#x016b;hala</em> mfn. one whose interest is diverted from (comp.) Vikr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-gati</em> mfn. one whose movement has ceased, abated, subsided, lulled (as wind) Kum </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-cetas</em> mfn. one whose mind is turned away from (abl.) Kath&#x0101;s </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-tva</em> n. the being separated or excluded from, inconsistency or incompatibility with (comp.) S&#x0101;h </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in phil.) the being separated from, the being non-extensive (= <em>alpa-de&#x015b;a-v&#x1e5b;ttitvam</em>, 'existing in few places', i. e. comprising but few individuals', said of a species, and opp. to <em>adhika-d"&#x1e63;-v&#x1e5b;&#x25cb;</em>, existing in many places', said of a genus) MW </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-deha</em> mfn. having the body split or burst asunder (said of a mountain) Hariv </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; transposed, altered ( See comp.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; expanded, developed, wide, broad, large MBh. K&#x0101;v. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; compact, firm, solid L. = <em>cchandas</em> below T&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;Br. Sch </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-ka&#x1e45;ka&#x1e6d;a</em> mfn. one who has arranged or put on armour, accoutred, mailed L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-cchandas</em> (<em>vy&#x016b;&#x0341;ha-</em> or <em>vy&#x016b;&#x1e3b;ha-</em>), mfn. having the metres transposed &#x015a;Br. AitBr </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x221a;">&#x221a;.</a><em>vyu&#x1e63;</em>) burning, scorching AV </dd>

           <dd><em>vrak&#x1e63;as</em> w&#x1e5b;. for <em>vak&#x1e63;as</em> Cat</dd>

           <dt>vraj </dt>
           <dd><em>vraj</em> cl. i, P. (Dh&#x0101;tup. viii, 79) <em>vr&#x00e1;jati</em> (m.c. also <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>vavr&#x0101;&#x0341;ja</em> RV. &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>avr&#x0101;j&#x012b;t</em> Br. Up </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>vrajit&#x0101;</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>vraji&#x1e63;yati</em> Br. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>vrajitum</em> MBh </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>vrajitv&#x0101;</em>, <em>-vr&#x00e1;jya</em>, <em>-vr&#x0101;jam</em> Br. &amp;c.), to go, walk, proceed, travel, wander, move (also applied to inanimate objects </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with acc. or instr. of the road, acc. of the distance, and acc., rarely loc. or dat., of the place or object gone to </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with or scil. <em>padbhy&#x0101;m</em>, 'to go on foot' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>up&#x0101;nadbhy&#x0101;m</em> id., lit. 'with shoes' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>dhuryais</em>, 'to travel by means of beasts of burden' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>param&#x0101;&#x1e43;gatim</em>, 'to attain supreme bliss' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>&#x015b;ara&#x1e47;am</em> and acc., 'to take refuge with' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>m&#x016b;rdhn&#x0101; p&#x0101;dau</em> and gen., 'to prostrate one's self at anyone's feet' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>antam</em> and gen., 'to come to the end of' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>anyena</em>, <em>anyatra</em> or <em>anyatas</em>, 'to go another way or elsewhere' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>adhas</em>, either 'to sink down <em>to hell</em>' or 'to be digested <em>as food</em>' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>punar</em>, 'to return to life') RV. &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to go in order to, be going to (dat., inf. or an adj. ending in <em>aka</em> [e.g. <em>bhojako vrajati</em>, he is going to eat']) P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 2-3, 15 ; iii, 3, 10 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to go to (a woman), have sexual intercourse with (acc.) Mn. Su&#x015b;r </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to go against, attack (an enemy </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also with <em>vidvi&#x1e63;am</em>, <em>dvi&#x1e63;ato'bhimukham</em>, <em>abhy-ari</em> &amp;c.) Mn. Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;. K&#x0101;m </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to go away. depart from (abl.), go abroad, retire, withdraw, pass away (as time) MBh. K&#x0101;v. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to undergo, go to any state or condition, obtain, attain to, become (esp. with acc. of an abstract noun, e.g. with <em>vin&#x0101;&#x015b;am</em>, 'to go to destruction, become destroyed' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>chattrat&#x0101;m</em>, 'to become a pupil' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>nirv&#x1e5b;tim</em>, 'to grow happy' [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x221a;">&#x221a;.</a><em>gam</em>, <em>y&#x0101;</em> &amp;c.] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>sukham</em>, 'to feel well' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>j&#x012b;van</em>, 'to escape alive') ib.: Caus. or cl. 10. P. (Dh&#x0101;tup. xxxii, 74) <em>vr&#x0101;jayati</em>, to send, drive, AitAr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to prepare, decorate Dh&#x0101;tup.: Desid. <em>vivraji&#x1e63;ati</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>v&#x0101;vrajate</em>, <em>v&#x0101;vrakti</em>, to go crookedly P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 3-1, 23 Sch</dd>

           <dt>vrata </dt>
           <dd><em>vrat&#x00e1;</em> n. (ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fr. &#x221a;2. <em>v&#x1e5b;</em>) will, command, law, ordinance, rule RV </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; obedience, service ib. AV. &#x0100;&#x015b;vG&#x1e5b; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; dominion, realm RV </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sphere of action, function, mode or, manner of life (e.g. <em>&#x015b;uci-vr&#x25cb;</em>, pure manner of life' &#x015a;ak.), conduct, manner, usage, custom RV. &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a religious vow or practice, any pious observance, meritorious act of devotion or austerity, solemn vow, rule, holy practice (as fasting, continence &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>vrat&#x00e1;&#x1e43;-&#x221a;car</em>, to observe a vow', esp., 'to practise chastity') ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any vow or firm purpose, resolve to (dat., loc., or comp </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>vrat&#x0101;t</em>, or <em>vrata-va&#x015b;&#x0101;t</em>, 'in consequence of a vow' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>asi-dh&#x0101;r&#x0101;-vrata</em> and <em>&#x0101;sidh&#x0101;ra&#x1e43; vratam</em>) MBh. K&#x0101;v. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the practice of always eating the same food (cf. <em>madhu-vr&#x25cb;</em>) L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the feeding only on milk (as a fast or observance according to rule </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also the milk itself) VS. Br. K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any food (in <em>a-y&#x0101;cita-vr&#x25cb;</em>, q.v.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>mah&#x0101;-vrata</em> (i.e. a partic. Stotra, and the day for it) Br. &#x015a;rS' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with gen. or ifc.) N. of S&#x0101;mans &#x0100;rshBr. (L. also 'month </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; season </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; year </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fire </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; '= Vish&#x1e47;u </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'N. of one of the seven islands of Antara-dviipa') </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>vr&#x00e1;ta</em>), m. (of unknown meaning) AV. v, 1, 7 &#x0100;p&#x015a;r. xiii, 16, 8 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a son of Manu and Na&#x1e0d;val&#x0101; BhP </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl.) N. of a country belonging to Pr&#x0101;cya L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; mfn. = <em>veda-vrata</em>, one who has taken the vow of learning the Veda G&#x1e5b;ihy&#x0101;s. ii, 3 (Sch.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; vratakamal&#x0101;kara </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>vavra&#x015b;ca</em>, <em>&#x25cb;citha</em> Gr </dd>
